review_title: Stay away from JBBBS (Jewish Big Brothers Big Sisters)
job_title: Match Support Specialist in Newton, MA
pros: When I started, I liked the job. It's less intensive work than other social-work positions, meaningful work, lots of writing (which I like), and you meet cute kids.
cons: JBBBS management turned into a nightmare. A few months after I began, the director of 20-years was ousted. I was working part time but pretty soon I had a full time caseload. I worked incredibly hard and often got positive feedback from families and volunteers (some of whom were board members, who told the CEO directly). I asked for a FT position and they said no. They hired a friend instead. Management exploited me, HR used my sick hours to cover up their mistakes, they gave jobs, benefits, and private offices to their less-experienced friends. They disregarded my safety - a would-be volunteer vaguely threatened me with a gun and management pressured me to meet with him anyway (I refused). When my son was injured and I had to take time off (thus my match support slipped - though I had been told not to focus on it so much), they took the opportunity to give me a work improvement plan. They ran me ragged and then told me I had a "bad attitude" even after being asked to mediate conflict between management and other employees. Obviously, I quit. JBBBS was about as far away from practicing the values that they preach. They were happy to bully, exploit, and disregard my wellbeing no matter how hard I worked.

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Lower-level staff are great. They really do hire great people.
cons: As you get higher and higher, here are where the problems begin. DEi/b practices are mostly for show. Something will be presented and it's either shot down, downplayed, or forgotten. Until a higher-up thinks of it. We lost 401k matching. Everyone is STRESSED. The job itself is easy, you just need to be good at keeping track of things and time management. But is it worth it when you are underpaid, can't speak out for fear of the CEOs wrath, new ideas are shot down (until a higher up or someone who gives us money suggests it). Since covid, we've taken on MORE work and MORE programs as if were still in the office. There is no work-life balance. since covid. Just them telling us to take time off but it's clear they don't understand how our work works. Taking a week off doesn't just mean the work will be there when I've come back, it will obviously but it will be that work, more work, 3 fires i need to put out and no one to fill me in. Workers rely on anonymous things like this because higher staff cant take any sort of criticism. Also DEI doesn't mean anything if your board is 98% old white men who have been here since Margaret Thatcher took office, Vietnam war and "president gorbachev tear down that wall". I do not even have time to address the racism- long story short, if you have any melanin, id advise you to steer clear of workplace. Which may be hard because sometimes if you apply to CB they send you to workplace anyways. BIPOC tend to not last there for very long. I mean the main perps are gone but...woof.

pros: Flexible hours and great employees outside of CEO.
cons: I feel it is imperative I bring attention to the issues involving CEO, Sue Johnson and the treatment of her employees because of the troubling pattern of behavior that has been observed. I have not worked for BBBS of Greater Birmingham since 2018 yet am STILL holding on to the contempt left by Sue. This should speak volumes about the culture created by her leadership. Upon hearing an update on how Sue is running the organization, it seems things have only gotten worse since I left. I felt it necessary to stand up for my former colleagues and the current employees still at BBBS unable to speak up. Due to board members being friends of Sue's it is impossible for employees to turn to anyone for help or guidance. During my short time at BBBS, I had multiple employees come to me in tears yes after being regularly YELLED at by Sue (along with similar accounts from former employees). Sue has created a toxic environment, and some would argue one full of emotional abuse and gaslighting behavior. Many employees are hardly paid livable wages, are yelled at and punished for things beyond their control, and I believe that after 25+ years as CEO, Sue is out of touch and a detriment to not only her employees but the organization as a whole. I would love to give more specific details but want to protect those that are still working there and doing justice to the wonderful mission. Please understand that I love the mission of BBBS and want what is best for the organization, volunteers, and - most importantly - the children they serve. It is for this reason, in addition to the ongoing pattern of troubling behavior that impacts individuals within BBBS, that I feel compelled to leave this review.

pros: Worked there for a number of years. The agency I belonged to was state wide, not just one city. That gives an employee a chance to receive a promotion if they're willing to move to different areas. The hours are relevant to your department (i.e. Recruitment is barely in the building 3 days a week for more than 4 hours). The staff in my city were amazing! Loving family and so on. There's always the 1 or 2 supervisors that think they run the office and make their department very uncomfortable but that is normal at any organization. As long as your work is done you then you're schedule is flexible. Remote work is available as long as you don't abuse it. Wonderful support system, they take the time to treat you well and repeatedly say "thanks" and "job well done". They usually promote from within.
cons: Short staffed due to expected set numbers (yearly goals are usually reached, and broken, but it felt that if you had an extra team member it would be easier to get there). Wages are typical low non-profit unless you're a head of department. The employees haven't received a raise in over 3 years even though they continue to raise more money each year. But they do hand out event tickets upon availability, gift cards and a small Christmas bonus depending on how long you've been there. Finally, unless someone leaves or retires, then you'll get an opportunity to apply for a promotion.

review_title: Meaningful work, but stay away due to low pay
pros:
* Friendly, warm atmosphere
* Program staff can focus on program goals
* Chance to work one-on-one with underserved populations
* Flexible telecommuting for some employees at some locations
* Work is often heartwarming and inspirational
cons:
* Embarrassingly low pay, not a living way for many areas. The starting wage hasn't increased more than $1,000 or so in OVER TEN YEARS. This is creating the impression in the industry that BBBS doesn't care about employee retention and that it doesn't matter that there's no continuity of care for the people we serve.  
* Outdated tools that haven't been improved in years. Staff is forced to work in frustrating, outdated ways that waste time and effort. 
* Flagging development work on the national level, few partnerships in the significant range. 
* Few opportunities to advance. Management has been in place in most locations for long periods of time. Low pay combined with no advancement forced to use outdated tools means ambitious, dedicated people leave quickly. 
* There is a major pay difference between the staff and leadership, instead of an appropriate difference, it's enough to contribute to inequality and a sense of resentment.

review_title: Talented and hard-working staff; great mission; lacks innovation and senior leadership lacks youth.
pros: Along with its great mission, BBBSA is a small enough national organization where you can learn a lot about non-profits, if you're willing to create learning opportunities for yourself. There are many smart and talented people from whom to learn. The work can be challenging (that's a good thing) and most employees are dedicated to performing well. This is the kind of environment where you leave the job but not the people. They stay with you.
cons: While the org is good at vision and conceptualizing the impact of its service model and outcomes, it cannot effectively execute its strategy. It lacks innovation. The folks in the trenches have great ideas and are willing to try something new but their voices are unheard. Senior management is overly cautious, glacial in its pace to make decisions, and has lost focus on its core mission and the importance of the people doing the work. A more trusting approach with its directors and business managers would serve the organization well.

review_title: not a good place to work
pros: other staff on the program level, made some great friendships very good people have worked there. Some of the matches that truly worked with caring volunteers who made a difference. Some great families participate in the program.
cons: It is all a numbers game. They chase funding that require unrealistic numbers program staff are meant to meet. Then when you struggle there is no support only intense pressure. It felt like a sales job, you are so desperate to meet your match goals it truly stops being about the people and ultimately the kids. there is an unrealistic expectation to call all the matches on your high caseload monthly as tracked by a computer program and if these goals are not met even if circumstances are beyond your control you are blamed and made to feel guilty. Inane phone surveys done frequently. Huge divide between program staff and funding, program put in a cube farm, others have nice offices. Large meetings where the CEO would talk yet have no idea about the basic way the program functioned.

review_title: Great organizational mission, terrible organizational management
pros: The mentoring mission of this organization is fantastic. You get to work directly with the Bigs and Littles, and it is really rewarding to see match relationships grow and the real-life impact that these match relationships can have on both the adult volunteer and the child. Staff members are generally very friendly, and they do a lot to try to recognize special occasions-birthdays, work anniversaries, and babies just to name a few. Also, staff members are generally very dedicated to the mission of the organization and really care about the Littles and their families, which is great.
cons: This organization is very poorly managed. Upper management does not truly care about staff, though they pretend to. Management regularly solicits feedback and suggestions for how to operate things better-however suggestions are never truly taken into consideration and things just stay the same. This leaves staff members resentful and generally unhappy. I'm not sure that upper management is really qualified for what they do-either that or they just seem complacent in their jobs and do not truly care how the organization is run. There is a very high turnover rate here, for good reason. The pay is also really low, even for non-profit.

pros: Job offers flexibility, you can set your own schedule most of the time; work with typically friendly volunteers and families; small office environment; not bad PTO
cons: Office building always has something broken or wrong (no heat but still expected to come to work, no hot water, broken sinks, gas leaks without being told about them, ants and mice around for months before management does something about them, etc.), low pay and no annual reviews or raises and generally very little appreciation shown from upper management- they raise expectations and amount of work without any give from them; no room to grow or move up; leadership micromanages, but doesn't offer helpful advice or stay on top of what you need them to do to be able to complete your job; matches are just numbers and everything is done for show- matches are made regardless of staffs opinion on whether a volunteer is fit to work with children or child is fit for program; terrible communication from management about things like special event days (what to do, when, how) and snow days (managers don't communicate until less than an hour/half hour before you're expected to be at work about working from home); Management expects you to willingly come in on days off or stay extra without compensation

pros:
- Great medical benefits
- A lot of Sick, Vacation, personal days and Summer Fridays
- Great co-workers and for the most part great directors 
- Good work-life balance.
cons:
- The Executive Director (or CEO, as he calls himself) leads almost like a totalitarian. Any great changes, he takes the credit for. Very narcissistic. We're a small enough agency and he barely knows anyone nor does he seem like he wants to unless you fit into his bottom line (this is not upsetting entirely, most would rather stay off of his radar and avoid scrutiny) 
- Other executives clearly feel the pressure from above and pass that along. They do however attempt to stand by their staff. 
- Since the year has started, there has been a consistent flow of 3-5 staff members resigning per month. It's unclear if upper management cares about this as there hasn't been any company culture changes to foster people staying. 
- Employee morale is dwindling, especially since upper management stripped their employees of 1 of their summer Friday's if they don't meet their fundraising (we weren't hired to fundraise) goals by a certain time. 
- Salary and raises are a joke

pros: GREAT! this company is amazing
cons: Increasing salary for workers, seems slim.

pros: Upon first being hired some years ago, I really loved the organization.  Yes, on first glance it was unorganized and a frazzled environment, but we got results as far as the children were concerned, and the staff at the national office were amazing.  They were just a great group of people to work with, and I finally felt like part of a great team.  But once the new CEO was hired and all of the layoffs happened, employee morale plummeted and has been down in the dumps ever since.
cons: We are all overworked and underpaid, and treated disrespectfully.  Also, care is not taken when hiring new employees.  All of those that have been hired of late, are nasty and have poor attitudes; their personalities don't mesh with those who have been here for some time.  There is a lack of communication across departments, and between managers and lower level employees.

review_title: very nice for freshers to start
pros: All the work is done within office hours
cons: ceo is bit hectic to handel

review_title: Two years of poverty to (maybe) launch your career
pros: It's a good career "starter." They hire people fresh out of college, so it's easy to get into the nonprofit world.  The office atmosphere is pretty casual and the staff is friendly.
cons: Though improving greatly, the agency was financially unsound for a number of years.  There has been high turn-over and the agency lacks "institutionalized memory."  Additionally, entry level staff are doing very difficult, emotionally taxing, and high-stakes work with inadequate training, support, and pay.  There is a condescending attitude towards program staff, and it is reflected in low wages and work hours that make it difficult to balance personal life.  There is a definite class divide between "us" and "them" when it comes to entry level versus management.  Program staff make less than 30k per year, and management doesn't seem to "get" why we don't rally behind fundraisers with our own time and money.

pros:
-Great employee appreciation
-Wonderful people to work with who really care about their agency
-Awesome mission
-Ability to work directly with the population and see the change
-If you're not in it for the money, there is a lot of personal reward
-I have the best supervisor that really invests in her employees and works around the clock to help her team.
cons:
-Often have to work late hours to finish work
-Pay could be better
-The process could really be streamlined, we are being managed from a company in a different area and it is unneccessary and really slowed down things. It affects how long the children and volunteers have to wait to be matched and it makes it harder for the employees.

review_title: A Great Start in a Supportive Environment
pros: The workplace atmosphere is the BEST of any place I have ever worked. All of the supervisors are wonderful, supportive, they listen to the staff and implement things we ask for like specific training and issues with workload. There is no workplace drama or unhealthy competition. Everyone helps everyone and questions are welcome. The office environment is friendly open and even fun. Also the schedule is very flexible so is perfect for people who have young kids. As far as social work goes, this is the positive end of the spectrum.
cons: To be honest, the only downside of working here is the pay and amount of workload. The pay is extremely low compared to other similar positions in other states, and even lower compared to  other agencies in FL. A lot of pressure to fund-raise is put on program staff even though there is a whole department for that and our workload is not decreased to accommodate the extra fundraising efforts. But this is the nature of working for a small non-profit.

pros: The people I work with every day are some of the most excellent individuals I've met.  The culture is much more laid back than a traditional for profit company, however this agency is still the largest Big Brothers Big Sisters affilliate in the nation.  Work life balance is actively supported, the job is supremely flexible and we traditionally get two weeks off around Christmas every year on top of PTO.  I feel like what I'm doing every day is helping kids.
cons: My current pay is in the 10-12th percentile of salaries in my field according to the BLS.  Form 990 shows executive pay in the agency much closer to the median.  Morale has suffered a bit due to the lack of raises over the past few years leading to high turnover.  We have lost several of our best people over the past two years.

review_title: They say they care, but it's all about quantity
job_title: Match Support Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Flexible hours due to the job type and compassionate upper management when needed
Super easy to get hired in the Los Angeles chapter
cons:
Senior team and Board is a joke. Had an interim ceo of a board member that went from the nonprofit mentality to for profit mentality. Worst months of my entire stay there. 
Completely unprofessional when letting people go. Made unexpected cuts to staff after an all staff meeting with everyone in an open room cubicle setting office. 
Didnt get a raise, bonus or anything in the time working there
They brag about quality but have high turnover. Mainly because of their true goal: quantity. After having tons of turnover (went from a team of 8 to a team of 4) continued to add new cases to caseload despite trying to pick up slack for the people we lost.

review_title: Local Affiliate Run By A Monster
pros:
Flexible Schedule
Great families
Great Volunteers
Wonderful mission/vision
Great National Agency
cons: Local agency is run by a woman who lies a lot. She is working on disaffiliating from the sponsoring agency and has literally left most of her staff high and dry to do so- then come back and tell them that they did things without her permission. She plays favorites and if someone knows more about something than her, she feels threatened and pushes you out the door. She is a bully and makes you feel like your opinion doesn't matter. She complains when you don't ask for assistance, then sees it as a weakness when you do. Then she's also not ever around for assistance. It's all just a hot mess with her and to think she's going to be running a state-wide agency soon... eeeeekkkk!!!

pros: Working with the kids was amazing. Seeing the impact that a positive adult has on a youth and specifically youth in need was amazing.
cons: They do not pay a living wage even when a bachelors degree is required. There is constant turn over which makes for an ineffective work place and lack of trust between clients and the agency.  There was no trust between ED & Match specialists. Board is ineffective and does not know how to operate as a board.  There was constant tension between the board and staff.  They also do not include staff in any strategic planning or changes with the agency. The president of the board is controlling, untrustworthy, and downright abusive. Don't work for this agency until the board has been overhauled. I was warned by previous employees not to take this job and I am now passing that warning along to others.

review_title: Don't be fooled by the non profit description
pros: Worthwhile, quality relationships with colleagues that will last longer than your employment here. Great opportunity to engage with many different parts of the Miami-Dade community through schools, through families and individually.
cons:
*Awful leadership
*Promotion based on "yes-people" or being liked not based on productivity or ability to lead successfully/manage others/collaborate
*Poor management & team building which leads to high turnover and resentment
*All about the partnerships with very little care for the kids/students/Littles
*Child safety concerns by matching Littles with Bigs who are high profile but have record of substance abuse or problematic background results
*Stretching the program staff thin/overworking
*Overtime not allowed to be reported even though it is required to meet the demands of the job

review_title: Great Company for Entry Level Experience
pros:
Opportunity to build connections with families 
Great entry level position straight out of social work school 
Great training department 
Great education program 
Summer Fridays and holiday parties are a bonus.
cons:
Low pay 
Not appreciative of the social work staff- According to ED " we are devoted to a life of poverty as social workers in the field"
Social workers are under utilized, we have amazing talent that goes unnoticed

review_title: Great Baby Step for a Career
pros: Great mission, mostly supportive environment, fun and positive work, PTO, great place to develop experience in the nonprofit sector and human services field in order to launch your career. Daily tasks are not complicated or challenging as far as effort. You get to meet a lot of people and hear all their stories! Immediate job satisfaction in finding mentors for children.
cons: Terrible hours for work/life balance, work weekends and evenings every week, goals are developed by upper management who have nothing to lose and all the pressure to achieve grant deliverables is placed on program staff, lack of transparency between executive leadership and program staff, high turnover, inexperienced managers who get promoted just because they survived the high turnover rate.

pros: The opportunity to work for an agency that is making an impact in the community is a great reason to work there.
cons: People are overworked, underpaid and under appreciated. Management is not good at fixing staff morale, instead they give more work and more expectations to staff members with no compensation. I paid for a course that was professional development and was only allowed a few paid days off work to take the week long course. They do not support their staff to grow in their respective professions. There is no room to move up in the agency. I have been there for three years in the same position and there is no management position for me to move up to. I would need to stay for 15 plus years in order to move up to the next position level.

pros: Amazing cause and mission that all employees are invested in. You know that people who work for this agency are working there because they genuinely care about helping children in the community. The experience offers a sense of reward that is hard to find in a corporate setting. The team is reliable and helpful when other employees need assistance completing a task. If the right management is in place it's run more like a business than a nonprofit organization. If you're interested in building a varied skill set, working for Big Brothers Big Sisters will expose you to a wide range of opportunities and roles.
cons: The working environment can be very unorganized and hectic. Employees are significantly underpaid, especially because you can expect to work overtime frequently, without compensation. The turnover rate is high due to long hours, low salaries and lack of management. It's easy to get spread thin when you're wearing 10 different hats, but that's not uncommon in the nonprofit realm.

review_title: Could they make it more depressing?
pros: Working with the children. That is all.
cons: Corruption. Miserable employees. Low-pay. They encourage you to under-perform so that they can get special funding. Disorganized, to the point that some adults slip through the cracks and don't get finger printed! Massive division between upper management and staff. Gloomy building that is falling apart with exposed wires next to sinks, mold, and gates that lock and people will be trapped if there is a fire. Overall, from the people you work with to the building you work in it's a miserable experience. If you walk in on your first day and not a single person welcomes you, and everyone seems stressed and depressed -that's a sign!

pros: Working with the kids, families and mentors - seeing the success of mentoring on the youth of the community.  Most co-workers are amazing, and become friends, and are in it for the mission.
cons: Management is self-absorbed and full of baloney.  CEO has been there too long (31 years) time for new blood.  Benefits and time off are hideous.  They should be better to compensate for low pay, which employees of non-profits expect but hope to have something else to balance the pay scale.  Employees asked to sign off on false documentation to ensure grant payments are made.  Good employees feel replaceable and management does nothing to retain them - reasons for resignations are not considered and are miscommunicated to other employees to make the employer look better.  Accounting practices are inappropriate.

pros: Great hardworking staff and mission.
cons: Horrible leadership. Executive Director changed her title to CEO to feed her ego. Lies all the time and has no accountability. The board of directors just blindly follow her and never question her decisions. High turnover directly linked to the CEO and her vindictive behavior. Pushed great people out the door. Gets praised by national and takes all the credit for the staffs hard work. Recognition and awards is what motivates this "leader". Positive feedback is not genuine and you can never succeed in her eyes. She thinks that she is the only person capable of good ideas and she will even say that. Constantly bad mouths people and other agencies. If anyone speaks up against the leadership they are degraded and pushed out the door. Continues to take on more work to make herself look better and make the staff work harder. When her ideas fail she blames everyone else but herself. Unbelievable that she continues to be praised and her practices are unquestioned.

review_title: Changes going in the wrong direction
pros: Benefits and a sense of purpose working for a company with an assumed great mission
cons: Upper and middle management makes little effort to be flexible with hours. Jobs are salaried so that there's no compensation for overtime, which is inevitable for almost every position on a weekly basis. The Chicago branch is too focused on business partnerships, resulting in the sacrifice of quality for quantity. Managers can't seem to find the balance between giving no support and micromanaging. Professional development does not seem to be a strong value of the company, so the HR trainings seem half-heatedly put together. The agency claims to be mission-driven, but below the surface, everything is about which partnership will make BBBSMC the most money.

review_title: Toxic workplace and tone deaf management.
pros:
- Strong mission 

- Majority of the social service roles are filled with caring and passionate case workers.
cons:
- The CEO and management are tone deaf. Families and kids served are continuously tokenized for fundraising purposes and pushed to attend and participate in public events as an example of how BBBS "changes lives."

- Majority of the staff are entry level social service positions, but little to no training is provided. They are often put into situations with families they serve extremely ill-equipped.
 
- CEO scoffs at any challenge or difference in perspective on how things are done, and bullies or gaslights those who stand up to him.

- Diversity of the Board of Directors is abysmal. 

- Absolutely zero room for growth.

review_title: Awesome Organization. A bit of disfunction.
pros: BBBS is a fantastic organization. The employees are amazing and it really is like a work-family. A positive and fun culture is important and Jacksonville does it well. Flexible schedules. Specific to this site, vacation/personal days are a plus!
cons: Questionable hiring decisions. It's unorganized. People work 24/7 with no real balance. Leadership doesn't allow employees to grow or take ownership of their day to day tasks. Glass ceiling issues. Understanding that everyone has something great to contribute, a well-organized orientation allows for employees to understand their roles better and allows for leadership to be a little more hands off while overseeing progress.

job_title: Site Based Program Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: The mission is great.  Serving youth and communities who need support and services is an admirable mission.  It's a rewarding job that allows you the opportunity to make a tangible difference.
cons:
Extremely low salary. Several thousand dollars lower compared to other positions in both non-profit and for-profit sector positions.

Zero opportunity to develop and grow.

Management encouraged to micromanage and stifle professional development.
No genuine effort made to show staff they are valued and appreciated.
  
Management and leadership seem willing to have a revolving door approach to filling positions.

Leadership places more effort in "increasing the number of children served" instead of focusing on running quality of programs.

pros: I enjoyed my co-workers and it was great getting to know the Bigs and Littles in the program. It is a good first job just to see what the real world is like - most people who work here are young and don't stay but 1-2 years.
cons: Attrition at this company is crazy. You work basically 24/7 for horrible pay and no bonuses, salary increase, training, etc. There is no opportunity for advancement even though they say there is. There is a lot of nepotism that happens in the company and the interactions that took place in team meetings were inappropriate. You would think that knowing what you are doing is providing a great service to the community and children would make working here wonderful, but the job is not really rewarding intrinsically.

job_title: Match Support Specialist in Morrisville, NC
pros: I liked working there - the people were great and management laughed a lot and told funny stories. We moved to a new building that was really nice.  All the furniture was new and we all got new computers. I had good health care, lots of sick days, flex time, holidays, fun team-building activities, and a lot of free lunches. It was a good place to work.
cons: The pay was low, but I knew that when I was hired so it was not unexpected. I was just happy to have a job since a lot of my friends weren't even working, or weren't working in their field.

review_title: Good organization, management could use some development
job_title: Enrollment and Match Support Specialist in Newton, MA
pros: Great organization that creates amazing relationships in the lives of Littles and Bigs across the country. In my experience, the co-workers were the highlight of the days in the office because of their deep passion for the mission and working to build communities of support through the match relationships.
cons: Because each branch is separate, it is much different than how a national non-profit would run. The management in my experience lacked a lot of the necessary skills to run a successful department and retain staff.

pros: The mission of BBBS is unparalleled and the work is meaningful. BBBS Lone Star is continuously implementing changes to be more proactive as an agency and streamline some processes. Transparency is a key part of the workplace culture, with weekly meetings to review current programs statistics and revenue.
cons: Training is inadequate and turnover is very high, especially in entry-level positions. The hiring  process is very slow (4-6 weeks) so that when someone quits, their caseload is distributed to other employees until someone is hired and trained. Pay is not competitive compared to other local nonprofits. During the beginning of each school year, programs staff are expected to sacrifice any work-life balance and work extensive unpaid overtime in order to meet program goals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Recognition for hard work is valued and in the forefront.  Culture of accountability results in high quality work and measurable, positive outcomes for the children served.  Rewarding mission and "work hard, play hard" atmosphere.  Promotion from within is common, which fosters professional growth and development among staff.
cons: Innovation is big and processes are ever-changing; employees must thrive on this and be highly adaptable in order to be successful and advance within the agency.  As with most nonprofit organizations, hours can be long and irregular at times.

pros: As with most nonprofits, our department has been downsized to 4 people, mostly happy and who all know our jobs. We do the work of 20 people and are given a set of HPA's (high priority activities) and do what we can, and leave the rest.
cons: We are 4 people doing the work of 20. Sometimes we don't always get acknowledged, and at times, the expectations are to achieve the impossible. Management has assigned us dashboards (job descriptions), but not always clear in their direction. "Other duties as assigned" has become more frequent.

review_title: Great mission. Leading the way for youth and families.

Management and CEO are champions for race, equity and diversity, and are implementing new values that focus on DEI. 
Employee benefits like work environment, casual dress, full benefits paid are great.
cons:
Only one of the senior leadership is of color (CEO), and only one manager is of color. Good mix of employees.
Huge waitlist of kids. Can't seem to raise enough money to keep up with waitlist.

job_title: Site Based Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I feel as thought the company provides great benefits (HMO & PPO Health, PPO Dental & Vision, 403B, and so much more). The benefits are also employer paid so nothing comes out of my paycheck. The team has a great atmosphere and the work we do is so meaningful to the community.
cons: Salary could be better, but it is a nonprofit. I knew what I was getting myself into. I don't consider it a Con, but we do work remotely 2-3 days out of the week. Also, there are evening and occasional weekends that I work. Other than that, I have none to share. I have enjoyed my experience.

review_title: A Great Opportunity for Recent Social Work Grads!
job_title: Senior Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: This organization does a wonderful job of offering great benefits and time-off.  There is some (very little) flexibility with schedules, however this was changing when I left.   Great people who are dedicated to the work is the biggest pro of all.
cons: Leadership is not always clear on goals of the organization and put pressure on individuals who are executing the work.  High turnover rate due to EdD who can lead with in more passive aggressive manner.

pros: The work the organization does is really needed for the community that they serve.  The youth in Essex, Hudon, and Union country strongly need mentors and this program gives them that with proven results.
cons: The organization is disorganized and unable see they are typically their biggest hurdle and challenge.  There also is high turnover due to unhappy employees and they need to self-assess to rectify their employee grievances to make sure they have continuity in staff.

pros:

-Giving back and helping those in need.

It's a casual yet professiona atmosphere and I enjoy being there.
cons: The non-profit pay. And the dental insurance could be better.

review_title: Every day the work I did positively impacted the lives of children for the better, forever.

A very supportive, engaged local board of directors.

Compensation needs to be based on the trends in the Houston market, not on the Dallas payscale - market.

Review and reward employees more regularly - as in their base salary.

review_title: I work for a wonderful cause & feel good about my work every day!

job_title: Enrollment and Match Specialist in Los Angeles, CA

Only people who get promotions are upper management, sometimes they invent new positions for them. Stingy about over time but they overwork you and don't pay well. They always say they don't have money.

review_title: Well run organization with a great mission
pros: I believe in the mission.  It is a well run organization, runs like business.  There are plenty of training and development opportunities.  Flexibility with work schedule.
cons: There is not a lot of room for growth.  Compensation has been stagnant over the last few years - however, it has been made up with more time off.  Some management could use leadership training.

pros: Great co-workers who share ideals, values and goals.
cons: Terrible system overall, that does not work to keep employees engaged, and does little to keep children safe. The CEO is completely out of touch with the programs department, and puts the integrity of the program below volunteer recruitment and revenue goals. There is little to no room for meaningful growth, because it is just accepted that the entry level positions are 1 to 2 years max.

review_title: Good place to start a career.
pros: Co-workers were great. Seeing the impact of your work is important and motivating, when we receive it. The job I did gave me a huge amount of very important and transferable skills. Learned a lot from this job.
cons: Despite learning a lot, did not enjoy the job in my day-to-day. Too repetitive. Also felt that the general atmosphere was very 'punch in, punch out' and very strict with working hours + workload. No benefits + pay is not great, but that is standard of a not-for-profit in a small/medium sized community.

job_title: Associate Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: It's a job with an agency with name recognition.  If you're desperate for a job, overall the pace of the work is sustainable and you don't have any safety concerns on the job like you would working in other social work positions with at-risk populations.  If you stay long enough you they typically promote from within. They allow for flex/comp time, though there are very specific restrictions to using it.
cons:
Very little transparency in the interview. They surprise you with a lot of duties that aren't included in the job description. As a licensed social worker the pay is very low compared to other non-profits in the city.  Does not provide clinical supervision hours. Extensive micro-management from supervisors. HR is very disorganized. Can't take vacation days for your first six months, which is double what most other non-profits in NYC have as a probationary period.  Management knows the agency is well-known and therefore go about their work with a lot of arrogance. Many of their practices are outdated and do not keep up with the advancement of technology. When you leave they can't imagine how there could be a better position or agency out there. 

Things they don't tell you in the interview:
1) Associate Program Manager is a fancy name for a standard caseworker.
2) Your caseload will be 55 matches, consisting of a child, parent, and volunteer. You will need provide support and have phone contact with around 165 people each month.
4) In my interview they said I'd work evenings two or three times a month. The reality is that once you have a full caseload it'll be two or three evenings a week. 
3) Each employee has to work at 3 fundraising events per year, which often occur on the weekends and go late into the night.  If a specific event is short staffed, your supervisor will call you in and tell you you're working till midnight that weekend, often with less than a week's notice. You are expected to work at said event even with conflicts in your schedule.

review_title: Staff give so much, but get so little in return
pros:
You get to meet a lot of bright students and (some) mentors that truly want to be a positive role model for under-serviced students.   

PTO and sick days accumulate very quickly (though, that's probably to offset the lack of money employees earn)
Most of my colleagues are genuinely good people with a wealth of experience and knowledge
cons:
Unfortunately, there are many:

1. Disconnect between management and front-line employees: None of the managers or directors seems to be aware of what exactly goes into all of the work front-line employees do. This is extremely puzzling, given that many of them were front-line employees at one point or another. Moreover, because of this disconnect, they set unrealistic expectations for employees and can't seem to understand why employee morale is so low.

2. Unrealistic performance goals: One of my biggest issues with this agency is that they're t about the numbers so much to the point that employees are expected to hit the same performance goals, regardless of how big their caseloads are or the issues facing their matches/programs.  Moreover, goals and  job expectations are ever-changing with little guidance from managers

3. Management: Managers tend to micro-manage their subordinates to the point that its overkill and makes you question your competence. At the same  time, managers will also drop the ball far too often, with the consequences falling onto their subordinates (but of course managers are never held accountable for these short-comings) 

4. Salaries/Job Roles: Salaries are far too low for a metropolitan area. To make things worse, a lot of front-line staff members have advanced degrees, so the pennies we're making aren't nearly enough to cover our student loan bills.  

5.  Work-life balance: Managers often claim that they don't want you to work outside of your work hours, but that's near impossible given everything program coordinators and match support specialists are expected to do

6. Job expectations:  The Program Coordinator role is basically two jobs in one (Match Support Specialist and Program Coordinator), Enrollment and Matching Specialist are spread too thin and are expected to have quick turnaround with all f their interviews, Match Support Specialist  have had their caseloads increase rapidly with little input in the manager,  job titles and roles often change with little notice

5. Morale/office culture:  Given 1-6, the office morale has been extremely low for awhile now. Across departments, staff feel like management values us little and fails to realize how thin we're spread.  On top of that, HR has made recent changes to make us feel even less valued. The CEO seems uninterested in getting to know lower-level employees

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Parsippany, NJ
pros: The one good thing about this place is that all the employees get along and are like family. Other than that I do not think I have any others.
cons: The company pays very poorly. The equipment they use keeps having technical problems, but they refuse to get better equipment and blame the employees for not reaching the quota. Also, the company keeps employees at part time so they do not have to provide benefits which are not great from what I've heard.

job_title: Director of Recruitment and Enrollment in New York, NY

cons: The only con to working at BBBS is learning some of the life situations of the children in need.  It is hard to imagine what some children go through in America and beyond.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Hard working co-workers, the team supports each other. They're all passionate about the mission and genuinely want to make a difference.
cons: Lack of transparency from upper management to staff, lack of professional growth, agency's upper management doesn't seem to care much about staff input though it's a small agency, huge divide between departments and upper management doesn't seem to address this. Low pay in a very expensive areas.

review_title: Great Mission, Terrible Place to Work.
job_title: Match Support Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: It’s a great mission and you feel a sense of pride for what you’re doing.
cons: If you start at the bottom it’s very difficult to move up.  Passionate employees are kept around until they burn out from overworking. Leadership doesn’t care about the mission, just about boosting their egos. The standards that national sets are impossible because they don’t consider sizes of the agencies.  BBBS also promotes a team environment, but anyone will stab you in the back without notice.

review_title: Amazing mission, loyal staff, questionable leadership and shaky finances.

cons: There is a lot of uncertainty about the finances of the org.  To some degree I believe leadership uses this as a tool to keep everyone on their toes.  It hasn't stopped leadership from receiving plush salaries.  M

cons: There's not a lot of money to make things happen; especially paychecks.  Last year, our office went through a two week unpaid furlough, as well as our benefits being cut drastically.  Nonprofits can be an uncertain place to work.

pros: The volunteers are mostly wonderful to work with and the salary isn't horrible.  All of the mandated travel and vehicle depreciation cancels that out though.
cons: The current CEO is directionless.  His ego is bigger than his vision planning and direction.  We have grown way too fast and cannot sustain our program.  Our youth suffer as a result, and staff turnover is VERY VERY high, as it is degrading to only work towards numbers and not towards actually making a difference in the life of a child, which is actually the organization's mission statement.  The staff are treated like they are robots and that they don't matter.   It is VERY frustrating work and shouldn't feel this way.

review_title: 'Numbers' taking priority over the work itself
pros:
Despite some of the previous reviews, I found the pay to be okay compared to other nonprofits. However, this does not mean the pay is not low. Considering the child safety risks the pay should be much higher, especially for those employees with outside experience! 

Good office location, nice office environment with snacks and coffee/tea.

You will gain strong case management and coaching experience. You will also become very familiar with all of Chicagoland and the different neighborhoods.

Business casual dress-code. Flex time. Expenses are reimbursed.

The agency is doing good work when it is done ethically and appropriately.
cons:
Non-programming staff refer to programming staff (essentially the social workers and case managers) as "line staff" which is offensive and dismissive. This reflects how they respond to any feedback from programming staff. We are the employees who are more connected to the children, families, and matches. Our feedback should be considered a priority. 

Participants are not happy with the direction the agency is going in. They feel unsupported, like a number, and matches are essentially operating independently. This is very concerning not only for safety but also for how any social service agency should operate. This feedback has been given repeatedly to mgmt and the CEO but no changes have come from it.

Staff without (appropriate and extensive) child development and social work experience are dictating how programming should be run, facilitating introduction meetings, etc., for the sake of making high goals. It is all done for the purpose of "serving more children" and because the agency is short-staffed but this lacks the consideration for the populations that we serve and their lived experiences. It also shows a lack of respect for the social work field and how skilled the employees actually need to be.

Also, the requirement for staff to participate in a fundraising event is problematic and contributes to a weird power dynamic. There are many reasons an employee may not want to participate including limited availability, wanting to engage in activities outside of their job (important for self-care!), having children to care for, comfort with asking friends/family for donations, feeling strained from long hours, etc. Upper management needs to listen to the feedback from staff. There is a clear consensus that this is an unpopular requirement.

review_title: Quite possibly the worst professional decision of my adult life
pros: I met some awesome colleagues throughout my time here. You'd be amazed by how strong relationships grew among us as a result of the shared suffering and collective chaos.
cons:
As the headline states, this was probably the worst career decision I made since graduating from college. It didn't start out bad, but quickly went on a downward spiral as I was there.

Management:
Leadership- and I'm using that term very loosely- is a collection of people who at best are in over their heads and at worst have no idea what they're doing.   The CEO is disconnected  from the realities of the work and seems to only be driven by numbers. He doesn't know how to relate to staff or the students the organization serves.  Upper management provides little pushback to continued changes  and/or support for their staff.
 
Compensation:
Program Coordinators,Match Support Specialists, and Enrollment and Matching Specialists  generally make $35-40k a year.  Even for the non-profit sector, this is on the low end of the scale for Chicago. If you have a Masters degree, I would strongly encourage you to look elsewhere and please know your worth.

Supervision/Support:
Supervision and support form your manager is very hit or miss; you'll likely either be micro-manged to no end or left to fend for yourself. A smaller segment of managers have  somehow  incorporated both styles into their management. Managers are quick to delegate tasks but slow to lead.  
 There have been a few managers that were actually good at their jobs, but most of them have fled this sinking ship. You honestly receive the greatest support and coaching from your peers.

Career Growth
To be honest, there is very little room for career growth here. Management knows that the vast majority of positions are entry'level,  yet they do very little to help their direct reports grow professionally. In fact, they seem content with keeping you in the same, thankless position with no opportunity to move upward.  At the same time, they expect you to give them at least a month's notice before you transition out to something better. 

Office Culture:
While most of the staff is friendly, the working environment is pretty toxic. Upper management can be very petty if they feel that you are not in lockstep with them.  Microaggressions are commonplace,  while diversity and equity issues are trivialized.  The organization mostly serves children of color, yet the majority of staff providing direct-services are white women and that majority of upper management is white and male.

In summary, if you are considering joining this team, I would encourage you to run, run for your life.

review_title: Good place to work if you have a big heart and don't need a high salary
job_title: Enrollment Match Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Working with the mentors and mentees is one of the most rewarding experiences you can have.  The jobs are clearly defined and depending on the management you have training can be thorough.

This was the most gratifying and fun I have ever had at a job.  Being able to help kids develop their literacy as well as life skills is priceless.  Received 2800 dollar education award for serving 900 hours.

Very flexible work schedule.
cons: Pay is below minimum wage.  The job basically works as a volunteer job, where you are paid a stipend regardless of the hours you put in.  The hours required are to grant an education award upon completion.  As a full time member I received $265 every two weeks.

pros:
make a difference in a child/volunteers life 
build stronger communities/schools
flexible work hours
bring dog or children to work
cons:
no advancement opportunities
no raises for 3 years
management didn't deal with office conflict and when they did they did it inappropriately 
moved from hierarchy to team structure back to hierarchy to hierarchy/team structure-- very hard to work in this environment when there are multiple bosses but team can make decisions.

pros: The people you meet in program staff as co-workers is what gets you through the days, weeks, and months. When I first started, we had a great group of people. We've had about 80% turnover this year so that group has dwindled. Those people are there for you to vent and help you get through your day when your frustrated. You need to make those friendships otherwise the road is going to be even tougher. The smiles on the kids faces when they meet their Big for the first time. The mission that this agency stands for is providing at-risk children with a mentor and many of them do make a difference in the life of these kids.
cons: Our office used to be separated into 3 counties but last year we combined into one office to make things more developed and to build a stronger team unit. This has seemed to backfire though. We are all in cubicles. There is a lot more talking and discussing that goes on and you realize that you are no alone in the way you feel. No one has had a raise in over 6 years on program staff. The pay is beyond ridiculous for many people who have Master's degree. They do not pay more for an advance degree or for speaking an additional language. Management does not seem to be considerate of people sitting in the cubicles who do not have an office door that they can shut.  They think by giving you a fancy coffee maker and a cookout that it makes up for it. The needs for the agencies outweigh the staff that is available. Goals are unreachable and unattainable but if you challenge the workload or have a concern you are threatened with being fired. Many of these sentiments have been echoed already by other agencies so it doesn't seem to be just us.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: It is very sad to say that there is not one positive aspect of working at this organization.
cons:
The Executive Director "CEO” is a verbally abusive man.  He puts people down not only privately but in front of members of this Senior Team and others.  He not only approves of backstabbing and talking behind each individual’s back, he encourages it.  He pins people against each other and then walks away.  Since he became an ED, almost every single month people leave the organization because it is unbearable to work with such an individual.  Moreover, because of his ways of running this organization, the Management Team that he has hired practices the same type of way of running their respective teams.  Each member of his Senior Leadership Team treats individuals on their team very badly.  They put people down and blame anyone but themselves if the outcome isn't what it seems.  
It has been a little over five years since this ED has been running this organization and he has had 13 assistants and all of them have left.  Some running out crying others leaving to lunch and never coming back.  
It is very sad that an organization such as BBBS has such an awful human being running their NYC chapter.  If there would be a new leader and team put in place then this organization would have the chance to flourish and grow but sadly, it will most likely only decline because no one is aware of what is really happening behind closed doors.
If you do choose to be employed by this organization, please remember that nothing this individual says about you or to you is a reflection of who you are.  He is extremely unhappy about his life that he needs to put others down to make himself feel better (as contrary as that sounds, it is true).  Anything that he may say, just let it fly by you and do not pay any attention.  However, if you can help to avoid working at this organization, please do.  It is a very negative and abusive environment.

review_title: Great potential and an opportunity to learn. High employee turnover
pros: The work you do has a direct impact on children in the community. Management is very vocal about a job well done.
cons:
The agency doesn't seem to value its employees. Managers are more focused on external numbers.
Even a competent employee could buckle under the workload.

pros:
-Good benefits
-Free t-shirt: If I didn't mention the t-shirt, I wouldn't have met the word minimum
cons:
-Office culture: TOXIC People are underpaid and undervalued BBBSMC, so they are always trying to find ways to move up the ladder. Your co-workers are willing to throw you under the bus if it could help them get even the tiniest bit ahead.

-Mission is just for show: BBBSMC values money over mission, sacrificing the quality of the program for the sake of increasing the number of corporate sponsors. Any effort that executive management makes towards professional development, is aimed towards the board liaisons and grant writers, not program staff.

-Management: Rather than facilitating progress, management hinders it. They have created a set of convoluted, redundant processes for every minute task. These, in turn, restrict any sense of creativity in their staff, forcing them to turn what should be a human, altruistic service into a mechanical and robotic effort to simply check a box. Promotions are rarely based on performance and are given to those with seniority--anyone who has stayed a year or more (a true rarity). This culture of micromanagement has chased the majority of good workers out the door within 6 to 9 months. 

-Hours: The hours are needlessly rigid. During the interview process, the managers promised flexibility and remote work. That was all completely untrue. You end up driving a great deal, working from early morning until late at night, and are never compensated for your time or effort. 

-Pay: The majority of staff members have graduate degrees, but are making significantly less than $30k.

pros:
- Flexible Schedule
- Working towards a good cause 
- Mostly a positive work environment
cons:
I worked in one of the Texas markets. They start you off at a low pay rate and make you believe there is a ladder to move up. However, promotions are far and few in between and raises are even rarer. Although most of the women in my office were kind, there were often times when I overheard dismissive comments about the LGBTQ community and snarky comments about one another. They work their new employees into the ground and wonder why there is such a high rate of turnover. As a young adult straight out of college, I learned that they target a younger audience in order to have cheap labor under the guise of "getting your foot in the door". 

In addition to that, my market went through a few lay-offs and did little to motivate the staff that their jobs were secure. It became even more clear to me that this corporation was no longer looking to serve our youth, but looking to make numbers in order to look good on paper. The office became a popularity contest when new ideas were thrown around. If a person who was well liked did not meet their goals or do their job, they were given a pass and often were the ones who received raises when there was money to spare. 

When I handed in my notice to leave, the managerial staff abruptly asked me to change my resignation date due to not completing work that I had done. I was asked to defend my job after giving them hard work and dedication over the course of my 2 year period of employment. I was backed into a corner and was sent on my way in the span of a 5 minute conversation. Management does not care about lower level employees unless they are working above and beyond, often disregarding their mental health and work-life balance. 

The company pushes recruitment of volunteers and mentors so hard, that the quality of mentors is often over-looked in order to reach certain goals. The majority of mentors that come in display a "white savior complex" and are not appropriately trained to handle certain hurdles a child of color would face. As a woman of color, I often tried to vouch for better cultural competency training for our mentors and staff but was told that it wasn't possible or that the resources were not there to provide such training. Again, this became disheartening as I truly feel mentorship matters only when it is quality. The managerial staff was predominantly white in both the corporate and market level, and often disregarded the problems our communities faced. Cultural training was only mandated at one hour per year, with few opportunities to gain more insight and little to no push to attend other trainings. Overall, this is not a company to work for long term.

pros: PTO is great, often received 2 weeks off between Christmas and New Years. Flexibility was nice in case of appointments/emergencies.
cons: The pay is not where it needs to be for the education and work required. They say it's because they're "non-profit" but that's only true to a degree. Turn-over is high. There is no advancement opportunities.

review_title: BEWARE! Sexism, lack of transparency, poor management, lies, and lack of direction!
pros:
The absolute BEST model for serving at-risk youth in need. Dedicated case managers who possess true passion and dedication to improving the lives of the families/children supported by their programs. Big Brothers Big Sisters maintains a positive perception in the community and with the stakeholders. Great relationship with local business leaders and media (see their board of directors). 

-Good vacation and benefits (then again most non-profits provide good benefits to compensate for low pay). 
- Truly meaningful and impactful work
cons:
Ran primarily by women who have created an atmosphere of deception, personal vendettas/agendas, and an overall discriminatory environment. (To be clear I have no issue with the gender ratio or women in senior management - however, I do not appreciate ABUSE of power). Sexism/favoritism were both very evident when they laid off three individuals (including myself) all male - without reason. Mind you, I was let go before the 6 month mark, so as not to raise their unemployment overhead. I was brought in and interrogated by the head of administration & finance (via office politics) after my integrity was undermined by disgruntled employees. A true low blow and cheap shot. Their programs suffer because the organization is prone to turnover and re-organization (twice in 2014). 

- Low Pay
- Unrealistic work expectations due to lack of resources
- Disorganized departments
-  Terrible management
- Lack of appreciation for hard work

pros: Great mission, most of the subordinate program members are nice to work with. Having my own office. Great families and kids.
cons: VERY high staff turnover, for a reason.  Employees are treated poorly, demeaning environment, fake praise that's not genuine.  A lot of backstabbing and gossip.  People wait for you to fail and call you out hard on it so you have no chance of getting ahead. Everyone talks about everyone else, it's hard to keep up. It starts with the top, the management is ego driven and not concerned about the kids in the program at all.  Several of us noticed that certain management lie and backstab other great staff so they get ahead, and this bred the culture that exists in all offices.  It's not the staffs fault that the CEO and Vice Presidents are ill equipped and several of us out perform them without trying. It starts with the top, the management is ego driven and not concerned about the kids in the program at all. There is no direction and no one wants to follow the management anyway.  Some staff were hired for one position and shortly after the start they are randomly put in another role in another office.  People count the minutes until they'd leave.  Number focused, not people focused.  People call the offices on average once a day to complain about something.  It's a shame that kids aren't first priority.  I would never recommend this organization to anyone, not even my worst enemies, to work at or to send your kids to.

You are on your own. So if you get hurt. You better be able to have your phone on you and not in the cab of the truck. Cause your screwed until someone finds your body where you drop.
Safety for you isn't a concern.

job_title: Database Specialist & Web Developer in Saint Cloud, MN
pros:
A mission that it seems like you can believe in, and while many chapters are great this one is not.

85% of the budget goes to paying staff salaries.
cons:
BBBS of Central MN is IRS audited yearly and the process begins with a fake bidding process, the same company always gets the bid because not only are they the only ones who know what to bid they donate a portion of the time and cost in a clear conflict of interest.  The company then gives BBBS of Central MN the full listing of everything that is going to be audited months in advance and another company comes in and pre-audits for free to find everything missing.  Once that is done BBBS  of Central MN can then produce all the missing documentation.  And even after all this there is still things on every audit report.

One of the most sexist and homophobic non-profits you will ever come across.  

Total lack of diversity at this office, even men are considered too diverse to fit in the culture. 

The average tenure of minorities is less then a year.  

Business casual for men is dress pants and a polo, business casual for women is cut offs and a t-shirt

Conflicts of interest in insurance vendor selection.  

Gender based limits on who will be matched: Men only to men, women to anyone.

Women can give unlimited references until they get 3 positive, Men give 3 references and are disqualified if any of them say anything neutral or worse.

Stereotypical male activities like hunting, fishing, camping, etc are heavily restricted because of association with guns, dangerous tools or spending longer periods together.

BBBS of Central MN also has unwritten rules saying LGBTQ people cant be matched with their gender of preference meaning many can never be matched.

Getting to hear phrases like "Yes, I know it is a sexist policy, but we need it because all men are violent predators," "Men should only be allowed to volunteer with their wives, then someone else can keep the predators in line," and "Men must shave daily, you all look like sex predators if you don't."

Being required to routinely work off the clock and not paid for it.

Mandatory trainings are considered as not working, including trainings run by BBBS and people are charged vacation time for going during business hours.

Requiring jury duty pay be remitted back to BBBS of Central Minnesota

Requiring vacation time for jury duty.

Illegal raffles, and forged raffle prizes.

Blatant Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 violations, in 2019.
